The company is planning to use the gRPC protocol with mutual TLS, which implies two-way SSL/TLS encryption. Network Load Balancer (NLB) supports TCP traffic but doesn't terminate TLS connections, so the traffic will not be decrypted in transit. Also, the gRPC protocol usually works best with TCP as it has its own built-in mechanisms for handling things like retries, load balancing, etc. This is ideal when mutual TLS is required for traffic between the client and the backend.

On the other hand, Application Load Balancer (ALB) does TLS termination at the load balancer level, meaning it decrypts and inspects the incoming requests, which doesn't meet the requirement of not decrypting traffic between the client and backend.
